Health
Sun 3/3/24 8pm bout of feeling high,  when i was sitting on the couch playing guitar and trying to sing.  I was feeling frustrated.  Started by feeling tired and hopeless, then ear ringing and fuzzy feelings around body.  I leaned into it and kept staring at a bag of chips on the table, and my vision became filled with static, and my eyes began blacking out a little.  I closed my eyes for a minute.   Then, it passed.   In think I probably could have refocused my eyes on something else and distracted myself through it.  Now, a few minutes later, I feel a little tired, somewhat relaxed, and a little worried about this sort of thing. I had Vyvanse at 2 today and half decaffeinated at 4:30pm

I think I need to stay keeping a daily journal.

Journal Feb 6, 2024

Feeling better today
It's Tuesday, took off sick yesterday, wfh today since lots of people are ooo, going to take the day off
Slept till 11:45, took Vyvanse around 10:15, helps with waking up
Restless night, but I slept with the cpap and I think it helped.  Took it off a couple of times last night, it's been a little uncomfortable, but I might just need to get used to it again
Sarah M texted me to give me another chance to respond. I did and now I feel better.  Also texted Mukul on my own to respond to his texts about returning my drill, and to see if he wanted to get food.  I feel good that I have plans for this weekend, and that Sarah invited me over without Sean, and she gave me an open invitation to come hang out.
Showered, listened to Rivi Shankur sitar music and then some Desi, felt good.
Going to go to fuel, then to PT
Watched the Harry Potter anniversary doc yesterday, it made me feel good, the moment between Emma Watson and Rupert Grint was genuinely touching.

Thursday

Got out just after 7, had a good Starbucks glass bottle Frappuccino.  took the underground to brick Street in west London for a corn beef pickles and mustard bagel.  It was very good.  The pickles were sweet,  would have preferred sour.  They were nice at the shop, the woman called me love.

Hit my head on the plexiglass seat divider while turning to look out the window at my stop.  Had a fun laugh with the woman sitting next to me who saw.

Writing this on a very packed underground train.  Amazed that I am getting to Westminster Abby before it opens.  Hoping to sign up for a Vicar tour. 

Did an audio and vicar tour at the Abby.
Sat in the house of commons for a half hour.
Climbed all 3 levels of the dome at st. Pauls cathedral.
Spend an hour at the natural history museum, saw some dinosaur skeletons and walked through some exhibits.  The exhibit on early humans was very cool.  Saw tools that were hundreds of thousands of years old, from non- homo sapient species.  Also saw evidence of cannibalism, a skull that was scooped out to be a bowl, and a Neanderthal skeleton that appeared to be intentionally buried.
Got a dinner at a small italian restaurant, penne bolegnese, not bad.
Saw six.
Went home and collapsed.'1×2vdgggdg2d

Thoughts from day 1 in London

London is a wet and cold place.  I have barely seen it rain here, but it always looks like it has just recently rained.  It boggles my mind that ancient people build a city here.

I am traveling alone, here for a week.  I am somewhat uneasy - I have had nice moments in the past while traveling alone, often filled with self-reflection.  But I have also had a lot of moments of lonliness, a kind of sneaking feeling of shame, and a desire to tell someone about what I am seeing and feeling.  Sometimes, I feel very off-script, like I am fumbling my way along and falling through moment by moment, experienving them but without the secure feeling that I am doing what is expected of me.  It is hard for me to go out and explore - I have before, and there are moments of confidence that come with it, but they just as easily collapse into moments of dead.  Writing this helps a little, though, even though it feels silly to write for noone.

I did have a nice experience today.  When I got off the express train from Hethrow, I walked to Buckingham Palace, since my AirBnb was not ready yet.  There was clearly an event happening, and a lot of people were stanging around waiting.  I did some googling and realized that it is the UK's Rememberence Sunday, their Veteren's Day.  I walked down to the Cenotaph, where I read they do their ceremony and moment of silence.  Standing in the crowd in front of Big Ben, Westminster Abby, and Parliament was a genuinely immersive and, for a moment, an exciting experience.  It was nice, because I do not often feel true excitement.  The brass military band sounded incredible.  The moment of silence started at 11:00am.  The crowd had slowly simmered down in the couple minutes before-hand, and when Big Ben tolled its jingle and started to strike the hour bells, it was dead silent.  This was one of the strangest feelings I have ever had, it was truely moving - true silence in a crowd of many thousands.  We could even hear a single child cry for a second.

As I walked out of the square, I saw a group of people standing around, so I stood and waited, too.  We say Charles and Camilla go by in their motorcade - I just caught a glimpse of them as they turned out of the gate to head back to the palace, waving as they went by.  I was probably 100 feet away.  I did not wave, but I wish I had, they were gone before I even realized I had seen them

One thing I noticed is how nice the police seemed.  None of them had guns, except for a couple standing by a gate used by the Royals.

After that, I walked up to a Starbucks, charged my phone (a plan that actually worked as expected), and got a "5-cheese toasty", a delightfully British name - the cashier was nice.  After walked to the Beatles old Apple office.  That was another cool feeling, thinking about standing there on the street while the played on the rooftop.  It looked just like in the Get Back documentary.

I began walking to Trafalger, but by that time I was getting pretty tired - I would had walked 20k steps before I got to the apartment, according to my watch.  I stopped along the way to get a charger for my phone, even though it cost 40P, and some toiletries from a small pharmacy.  I heard two different women come in and talk to the shopkeeper - it was very folksy, they described their symptoms and he recommended some product for them.  I heard him mention to the one woman that, if she was a smoker, she should take (some syrum), because it would draw out the toxins and heavy metals.  He seemed like an extremely friendly man, possibly greek or turkish, but it reaffirmed my belief that off-hand advice, even from professionals, should be treated skeptically.  The woman who checked me out was kind.

I got into the apartment around 2pm (I took a chance and let myself in early, I needed to put my stuff down).  It is very small, just a bed, about a 2' perimeter, and a tiny bathroom.  I think it will be enough space for me, though.  I spread my stuff out, charged my phone, texted Yan back (it had been a few days) and read on my tablet for a couple hours before falling asleep accidentally, till 8! (despite waking up a could times and thinking about how I should get up).

After much indecision, I decided to head to the area around Victoria Station, becuase there weren't really any causal restaurants around me.  I tried to take the bus, but my express train ride from Heathrow was much more expensive than I thought, so I didn't have any money left on my Oyster card.

I got a great lamb halal wrap with fries from a place called Wrap City.  The guy there was unbelievably kind.  I was a little uncomfortable and unsure, but it was a good experience.  Then, I walked to a convenience store in Victoria Station, got two bottles of water (which were too cold to hold and I had to stuff into my jacket pockets, which looked a little silly), and some peanut M&Ms.  I walked back the way I had came, past Buckingham and throgh Green Park, which is a little eary at night and very dark, but the mist and the warmish, dim lamps gave it a cool ambiance.  I got home and started writing this!

I feel like I notice a lot of things that are different here than in America, and certainly some are like the outlets, the taxis, etc, but I find myself wondering a lot how much at home I take for granted.  After all, different cities, especially in areas of new constuction, have all sorts of new signage, traffic patterns, pubs that look English, etc.  Maybe there is so much that is new in America that it is difficult to tease out an authentic local culture.  Or maybe, every city has it's own new quirks, and London has it's own strong brand of new and old visual motifs.

The last thing I noticed today is how I think about people that are not from my country.  Something about people with British accents makes me imagine them much more generously - they feel real and kind.  I never really noticed this before, but I am very skeptical of other Americans I meet.  I feel like I already have a sense of who they are when we meet, and it feels like a lot of people are posing, and that they are not kind, or that I can already feel their weaknesses and disappointement.  I wonder why I feel this way, maybe it is a manifestation of old trauma.  Maybe Americans really aren't as kind?  I am not sure, but that's probably not the case.  I always feel this way about asian people I meet, too.  Is it because I imagine more complexly, or less?  I'll have to keep thinking on it.

My legs and back are pretty tied, but overall I feel good. Hoping to get up around 9 tomorrow, maybe leave around 9:30~10 ish and head to the British Museum.

Thoughts from day 1 in London
London is a wet and cold place.  I have barely seen it rain here, but it always looks like it has just recently rained.  It boggles my mind that ancient people build a city here.
I am traveling alone, here for a week.  I am somewhat uneasy - I have had nice moments in the past while traveling alone, often filled with self-reflection.  But I have also had a lot of moments of lonliness, a kind of sneaking feeling of shame, and a desire to tell someone about what I am seeing and feeling.  Sometimes, I feel very off-script, like I am fumbling my way along and falling through moment by moment, experienving them but without the secure feeling that I am doing what is expected of me.  It is hard for me to go out and explore - I have before, and there are moments of confidence that come with it, but they just as easily collapse into moments of dead.  Writing this helps a little, though, even though it feels silly to write for noone.
I did have a nice experience today.  When I got off the express train from Hethrow, I walked to Buckingham Palace, since my AirBnb was not ready yet.  There was clearly an event happening, and a lot of people were stanging around waiting.  I did some googling and realized that it is the UK's Rememberence Sunday, their Veteren's Day.  I walked down to the Cenotaph, where I read they do their ceremony and moment of silence.  Standing in the crowd in front of Big Ben, Westminster Abby, and Parliament was a genuinely immersive and, for a moment, an exciting experience.  It was nice, because I do not often feel true excitement.  The brass military band sounded incredible.  The moment of silence started at 11:00am.  The crowd had slowly simmered down in the couple minutes before-hand, and when Big Ben tolled its jingle and started to strike the hour bells, it was dead silent.  This was one of the strangest feelings I have ever had, it was truely moving - true silence in a crowd of many thousands.  We could even hear a single child cry for a second.
As I walked out of the square, I saw a group of people standing around, so I stood and waited, too.  We say Charles and Camilla go by in their motorcade - I just caught a glimpse of them as they turned out of the gate to head back to the palace, waving as they went by.  I was probably 100 feet away.  I did not wave, but I wish I had, they were gone before I even realized I had seen them
One thing I noticed is how nice the police seemed.  None of them had guns, except for a couple standing by a gate used by the Royals.
After that, I walked up to a Starbucks, charged my phone (a plan that actually worked as expected), and got a "5-cheese toasty", a delightfully British name - the cashier was nice.  After walked to the Beatles old Apple office.  That was another cool feeling, thinking about standing there on the street while the played on the rooftop.  It looked just like in the Get Back documentary.
I began walking to Trafalger, but by that time I was getting pretty tired - I would had walked 20k steps before I got to the apartment, according to my watch.  I stopped along the way to get a charger for my phone, even though it cost 40P, and some toiletries from a small pharmacy.  I heard two different women come in and talk to the shopkeeper - it was very folksy, they described their symptoms and he recommended some product for them.  I heard him mention to the one woman that, if she was a smoker, she should take (some syrum), because it would draw out the toxins and heavy metals.  He seemed like an extremely friendly man, possibly greek or turkish, but it reaffirmed my belief that off-hand advice, even from professionals, should be treated skeptically.  The woman who checked me out was kind.
I got into the apartment around 2pm (I took a chance and let myself in early, I needed to put my stuff down).  It is very small, just a bed, about a 2' perimeter, and a tiny bathroom.  I think it will be enough space for me, though.  I spread my stuff out, charged my phone, texted Yan back (it had been a few days) and read on my tablet for a couple hours before falling asleep accidentally, till 8! (despite waking up a could times and thinking about how I should get up).
After much indecision, I decided to head to the area around Victoria Station, becuase there weren't really any causal restaurants around me.  I tried to take the bus, but my express train ride from Heathrow was much more expensive than I thought, so I didn't have any money left on my Oyster card.
I got a great lamb halal wrap with fries from a place called Wrap City.  The guy there was unbelievably kind.  I was a little uncomfortable and unsure, but it was a good experience.  Then, I walked to a convenience store in Victoria Station, got two bottles of water (which were too cold to hold and I had to stuff into my jacket pockets, which looked a little silly), and some peanut M&Ms.  I walked back the way I had came, past Buckingham and throgh Green Park, which is a little eary at night and very dark, but the mist and the warmish, dim lamps gave it a cool ambiance.  I got home and started writing this!
I feel like I notice a lot of things that are different here than in America, and certainly some are like the outlets, the taxis, etc, but I find myself wondering a lot how much at home I take for granted.  After all, different cities, especially in areas of new constuction, have all sorts of new signage, traffic patterns, pubs that look English, etc.  Maybe there is so much that is new in America that it is difficult to tease out an authentic local culture.  Or maybe, every city has it's own new quirks, and London has it's own strong brand of new and old visual motifs.
The last thing I noticed today is how I think about people that are not from my country.  Something about people with British accents makes me imagine them much more generously - they feel real and kind.  I never really noticed this before, but I am very skeptical of other Americans I meet.  I feel like I already have a sense of who they are when we meet, and it feels like a lot of people are posing, and that they are not kind, or that I can already feel their weaknesses and disappointement.  I wonder why I feel this way, maybe it is a manifestation of old trauma.  Maybe Americans really aren't as kind?  I am not sure, but that's probably not the case.  I always feel this way about asian people I meet, too.  Is it because I imagine more complexly, or less?  I'll have to keep thinking on it.
My legs and back are pretty tied, but overall I feel good. Hoping to get up around 9 tomorrow, maybe leave around 9:30~10 ish and head to the British Museum.

There are many useful features in UpNote to help you stay organized and productive.

Add notes to notebooks 📚

  • Add your notes of the same topic into one or multiple notebooks
  • Create nested notebooks to better organize your notes

Organize with hashtags #️⃣

  • Simply type # to add hashtags anywhere in your note #UpNote
  • All hashtags will show up on the side bar and in the note’s info panel
  • Hide unused tags and notebooks from the side bar to keep your workspace clean. Click on the Tags/Notebooks labels to view all Tags and Notebooks

Find your notes quickly

  • Pin a note to the top of the note list 📌
  • Add your notes to Quick Access ⭐️so you can refer to them anytime

Writing with Markdown 📝

  • Check out this article for the full Markdown syntax used in UpNote
  • You can paste from Markdown source into UpNote by right click > select Paste with Markdown

View your note’s info

  • Click on the Info icon to show your notes’ info: date, word count, backlinks, tags and table of contents

For Mac, Windows and Linux apps


Stay focused when writing 🏹

  • Write without any distraction with Focus Mode. Use shortcut Cmd + Shift + F to quickly toggle the mode
  • Turn on Typewriter Mode when you write a long note to keep the text in the middle of the screen. Use the shortcut Cmd + Shift + T to toggle between normal and typewriter mode

Keep window on top 📍

  • Take note while reading or learning online conveniently by sticking the app on top of your browser windows
  • Click on the icon at the top right of your notes window or use the shortcut Cmd + Shift + K

Import & Export 📃

  • Import your notes from Evernote or other file types including Markdown, HTML, RFT/RTFD, Doc/Docx and TXT
  • Export your notes to various formats: PDF, Text, HTML and Markdown

Web clipper extension 📋

  • Quickly save links and content to UpNote when you browse and research on the web
  • Download Web clipper extension for Chrome, Firefox and Safari

Hope these features are useful for you. For more information and updates about UpNote, please visit our blog and follow UpNote on Twitter. If you have any feedback or suggestion please let us know at support@getupnote.com. Happy writing! 😃

Welcome to UpNote!

Thank you for using UpNote and we hope you will enjoy it.

UpNote is designed to help you take notes quickly and keep them organized. Here are some ideas to help you make the best use of UpNote.

Create a checklist to manage your todos:

  • Finish homework by Friday
  • Book ticket for summer vacation
  • Return library books

Write your thoughts with rich formatting:

  • Use list and nested list, like this:
    • Write text in bold, italic, underline, strike-through
    • Highlight text in multiple colors: orange, red, blue, yellow, green and purple.
  • Select your preferred font in Settings
  • Add a link to your note

Add an image



Add a quote

Knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.
―Aristotle


Add a code block (Premium⭐)

const message = 'Hello World'
console.log(message)


Organize note content into table (Premium ⭐)

Subject Grade
Physics
Practical
 A
Theory
 B+

Link between notes 🔗

  • You can link to other notes, for example see Explore UpNote features
  • To link to another note, simply type [[ and you can select the note you want to refer to. (You can find out more about note linking here)

Sync notes across devices 💻📱

  • Create a free account and log in to your devices
  • You can use UpNote on iPhone, iPad, Mac, Android, Windows and Linux

Unlock full power of UpNote with Premium

  • Upgrade once and use on all devices
  • Check out Settings > Premium for more details ⭐

Thank you for trying UpNote!

If you have any questions or suggestion, please write to us at support@getupnote.com, we love to hear from you! If you enjoy UpNote, please take a moment to rate it on the App Store, Play Store or Microsoft Store. We greatly appreciate your support!

- UpNote Team
